DIV1.P: PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL DRURY LANE.
DUBLIN: PRINTED FOR H. CHAMBERLAIN, R. MONCRIRFFS, W. COLLES, W. GILBERT, G. BURNZT, W. WIL∣SON, L. WHITE, P. RYRNE, P. WOGAN, H. COLBERT, J. MOORE, . DORNIN, AND J. JONES.

LG.L: THE Comic Muse, tho' privelig'd to wear
A mask on her own face, strips others bare,
And whilst she gives all nature to your view,
Shall not her mirror shew th' Impostor too?
For tho' most knaves in this ingenious age
Out-trick the law, we trap them on the stage:
But then some poets make their knaves so witty,
That when they pluck their vizors off, you pity.
Now that's a fault of poets dead and gone,
Our bard has kept his conscience clear for one;
Indulge his knave in a few roguish fallies,
To call him witty wou'd be down right malice;
His bitterest enemies, with all their railing,
Are well dispos'd to'acquit him of that failing.
Time was indeed, but that good time is past,
When novelties did not grow old so fast:
Woe to the piece, tho' st first sight 'twere striking,
If second sight steps in and mars your liking!
Like a new face, it glitters for a day,
All run, crow'd, follow; slare—and turn away.
Love hath it's honey-moon, but, that once o'er,
From sweet to flat, from flat it turns to sour;
Cross follows cool, as cool succeeds to civil,
My duck! my darling! once, and then—My devil!
Ev'n Wit's fine edge is dull'd by too much wearing,
And truths twice told will tire us in the hearing:
The Orator, that tries his lungs too often,
Will set the lungs of other men a coughing;
No sooner up, than strait all parties join
In one unanimous resolve—to dine;
The lessening senate melts away by drops;
And metaphors are left for mutton-chops.
How then? If novelties be so uncertain,
Sad news for our old friend behind the curtain,
Whose Muse has push'd her helicon about
So quick, we almost fear the tap is out:
If truth, wit, eloquence are but a Jest,
How shou'd a mere Impostor stand the test?
I'll give the Bramble's answer to the Oak,
Small sticks will blaze, when great ones only smoake.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT 1.
DIV2.STAGE: A Saloon in Sir Solomon's House.
Sir SOLOMON SAPIENT and Captain GEORGE SAPIENT meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: GEORGE.
SP.P: GOOD morrow to you, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Most valorous and renowned cap∣tain, give me your hand. How fares it, my brave fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I am glad to see you so merry, brother So∣lomon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Merry and wise too, or I have that name for nothing. I warrant now you have had your turn upon the terrace, pacing up and down to the measure of your old quarter deck—isn't it so?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Aye, aye, habit is every thing. Is your noble guest the Viscount Janus stirring yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Not yet, not yet: I am waiting here to give his lordship the good morning.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then you must n't wait much longer let me tell you, or it will be mid-day before his morning's be∣gun: give him a good rowze instead of it and pipe all hands to breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: What kind of manners wou'd that be, friend George? We must have no rowzing nor piping here; no such sea noises with a nobleman of his high birth and breeding. Where are all my fellows? Where is Oliver?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Here am I, your worship; here is Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And a precious Hottenot you have made of yourself: Is that a trim to wait upon a lord in? Go, get you gone, you lazy whelp, and let me see you in your new livery; slip on your other skin, and then present my compliments to Lord Janus and beg to know how he has rested.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Chearly, my good fellow! dowse your soul weather flag and hoist your holidays colours in ho∣nour of the occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Well, if it must be so, it must, your wor∣ship; but I'd as soon be set in the pillory as foisted into that new fangled doublett.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And hark ye, Sir, a word with you—Let me hear no more of your worship; leave off your quarter-sessions cant, and speak to me in a language such as well-bred ears are us'd to.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: As how forsooth?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P:
This it is: when you speak of me, let it by my proper stile and title, Sir Solomon Sapient;
when you speak to me, simple Sir Solomon will suf∣fice.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Simple Sir Solomon, it shall suffice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: The Czar Peter was not more plagu'd to trim the beards and whiskers of his Muscovites, than I to trim these clod-pated bumpkins out of their long skirts and pudding-cuffs.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And after all do you think 'em worth the pains? Surely my friend Oliver is at least a match for Monsieur Philibert, the little ugly Jew-like fellow, that calls himself Lord Janus's valet de-chambre. His-lordship's suite is not very splendid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: That's true, George; you say true; Lord Janus does not affect pomp; he travels as it were in∣cognito. His lordship at this distance from the capital may be liken'd to a comet in the extremity of its orbi when he approaches to the point of his attraction he will send forth a shining and a brilliant train: Lord Janus is a man of speculation and enquiry.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And shou'dn't you be a man of enquiry too-brother Solomon?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And where wou'd your wisdom send me to enquire? Of Collins's Peerage? I have his pedigree by heart; I can trace him from the heptarchy; his very title of Janus proves the circumspection of his ancestors; 'tis as much as to say they had all their eyes about 'em: his armorial bearings are typical of sagacity; two vizors in a wreath of serpents: his sup∣porters are an allegory; on the dexter side a fo denoting cunning; on the sinister a goose, which is the emblem of wariness.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I wish you wou'd take a lesson from that wary goose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I shall take a lesson from no goose, nor go to one for counsel, so pr'y thee spare your pains in ad∣vising me; why will you concern yourself in a business, that is out of your line? why will you be thrusting in your oar?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: 'Twou'd not be the first I've handled by a pretty many, if I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Then keep to your element, dear George, keep to your element, the boisterous ocean: you have not made human nature your study; you have not been in the world as I have.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I have been round it, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Aye, there's the case, you have peei the orange but not tasted the fruit. I am the man, the happy man, who when I first set eyes upon this noble peer, intuitively develop'd all the latent virtues of his heart; and now you shall know, George, that I ex∣pect his lordship to propose for Eleanor out of hand.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I don't doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And why don't you doubt it?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Because my niece will have a fine fortune, and what is more is a very fine girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Hush! here comes Monsieur Philibert.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Ah! bonjeur, gentlemen bote? I have de ho∣nor to wish you de very good morning; to my noble patron premiérement, and to Monsieur le Capitaine also.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Good day to you, Monsieur Philibert: I hope your noble lord and master rested well last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I tank you; Grace a Dieu, he has slept like a leetle pig; he make you very many baisemains, and demand ten tousand pardon, for dat he is occupèe with one gentleman, who is juste arrivè de Londres with beaucoup d'affaires for him and papiers, ma foi, plus interressantes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Who is the gentleman, may I ask!

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Ah! he is very great man to mi lor, he is all in all to my lor, his advocat, his what d'ye call it, his homme d'affaires, his Monsieur, Monsieur—(peste!) Ah! je comprens—Monsieur Polycarp—Mais, voila! mi lor. soi meme—Ah! je suis ravi, he is habiliè to a merveil.
SP.STAGE: [Lord Janus runs in and embraces Sir Solomon.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: My dear Sir Solomon, I have broke from business to embrace you and apologize for the intrusion I have made upon your morning hours by the sudden arrival of my friend and agent Mr. Polycarp, a very necessary man to my affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: My lord, my lord, I pray you no apology to me: san't I have the honour of seeing the gentle∣man?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Your politeness overpowers me: Mr. Polycarp is a most excellent man, unwearied in his at∣tentions to my interest; he is in fact my right hand, a very trusty person and a true friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Good my lord, any friend of your's must be welcome here: I pray you make my poor house your own. Won't you be pleas'd to send to the gen∣tleman? or shall I attend upon him?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: By no means—Philibert, couez! Go to Mr. Polycarp and tell him I shall have the honour of presenting him to Sir Solemon.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I go, mlor.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Worthy Captain Sapient, I kiss your hands: I protest I did not see you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: My lord, your very humble servant—If you are upon business I beg I may retire.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: I humbly entreat you will not; I flatter myself you will stay and be my advocate with your lovely niece, when I have Sir Solomon's permission to cast myself at her feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I fancy your lordship will want no advocate there.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: It transports me with joy to hear you say so—The arrival of this gentleman is most opportune for my wishes; he is perfectly confidential and will satisfy you in all particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: My Lord, this conduct is truly noble and explicit, and be assur'd your lordship's alliance cannot fail to reflect the greatest honor and happiness upon me and my family—This is the gentleman I presume
SP.STAGE: POLYCARP enters follow'd by PHILIBUAT carrying two red trunks for papers, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: This is my friend Polyearp, Sir Solo∣mon—Mr. Polycarp, I have now the pleasure of mak∣ing you known to my honor'd host Sir Solomon Sapient, a gentleman from whom I look to derive all my fu∣ture happiness in life: This, Sir, is the brave Captain Sapient, brother of Sir Solomon, a name that does honor to the naval annals of Old England.

SP.SPEAKER: Polye.
SP.P: I honor both the one and the other as I do the mirror of wisdom and the soul of valor [howing to each alternately]—Sir Solomon, I blush to say I must begin my acquaintance by requesting a favour of you. Here are two trunks belonging to my noble client; their contents most valuable and important; request a safe deposite for them in your strong box or closet: we can never be too careful of the property of our employers.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: That is so like your methodical forma∣lity, friend Polycarp; I dare say there's nothing in 'em but some fusty parchments.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I don't know how fusty they may be, but I know they are good for ten thousand a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: If they were ten times ten they shall be for thcoming. Brother George, have the goodness to put them in my iron chest in the audit chamber: here in the key.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir Solomon, I cannot think of Captain Sapient being troubled with such lumber.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Not at all, my Lord, no trouble at all, I'll stow'em away safe never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: And if you take 'em for your pains you'll have no prize.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Seriously, Mr. Polycarp, this is being too punctilious, as if they wou'd not be safe enough any where in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I hope this house will have an interest in them by and by, my lord; at present you must let me take my own way.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Well, well, be it so! I hope they con∣tain wherewithal to furnish a good jointure for the loveliest of women, and for a clear title and a clean property I trust my deeds may vi with any man's, as Mr. Polycarp can witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Yes, truly, were all men's deeds like your lordship's, there wou'd be little employ for the con∣veyancers—The hangman's office would have all the custom.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: And now, my good Sir Solomon, a truce to business; let us attend upon the ladies at theis deje.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: With all my heart: Who waite.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Your worship—(hold, there again; simple Sir Solomon will serve or this turn) what are your commands?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Oliver, where is my cousin Dorothy and my daughter Eleanor?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Madam Dorothy, so please you, is ex∣pecting you at the breakfast table, and under favour the good ly fumes as furiously as the tea kettle; she is cruelly out of patience: Mise Eleanor is not yet come in from her ride.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: So we go on in the country, Mr. Poly∣carp, fresh air and wholesome execise, a gallop on the downs before breakfast, and a plunge into the cold bath for a bracer; this in our regimen; these are the only beauty washes we make use of.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: No wonder my noble patron here cannot stand the battery, when his fair assailant keeps her artillery in such order.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Ah! Polycarp, when you behold the charmer—

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I do behold a charmer.
SP.STAGE: Mrs. DOROTHY enters, as POLYCARP is speaking, and curtsies to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: No, no, Mr. Polycarp, that is only cou∣sin Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Lord love your hears, this is not our Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Silence, ruffian!

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Aye; aye, taisez vous, Monsieur Olivier, taisez vous.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Not I, I have no desire to taste.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Permit me, lady fair, to present to you my friend Mr. Polycarp, a bachelor and a very great practitioner I assureyou; Mr. Polycarp's is a name well known at the bar.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, I may boass of having made some little figure there in my time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Your good breeding will intitle you to figure any where—

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: With so fair an advocate to recommend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: In politer courts than those of West∣minister Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: In the chamber of the ladies I should be most proud to be a counsellor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Your good address, Sir, cannot fail to recommend you o the good graces of the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: There is one I must confess I am interested to be known to in the most favorable light.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: The lady must stand greatly in her own light, who does not favor so much modesty and re∣finement of behavior. Shall I have the honor to shew you the way to the breakfast room?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Gratify me in the mean time with the felicity of your fair hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Upon my word, Lord Janus, this friend of yours is a man of great gallantry.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: The veriest Philander in nature: Allons! let us follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: He bien! Monsieur Olivier, what you tink of all dis? will your young lady marry milor?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: That's hereafter as it may be, Mounseer.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: As it may be? she may be one very happy voman with mi lor.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: So his worship seems to think.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Ah! his vorship is very vise man indeet to tink so; he have all de sagesse of king Salomon him∣self; and upon my vort his vorship make very pretty liverie for de matrimonie of his daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Yes, and methinks 'tis not unlike matri∣mony, for it sticks plaguy close to a man; when a body's once in it, these's no getting out of it: mark how these two slappets fly asunder! there's more matrimony for you; man and wife can't quarrel with a better will.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Aye, aye, 'tis in de last cut of the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: I wish it may prove the last, for I never desire to wear such another.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Pardon me, you wear it very well—turn yourself about, mon ami, let-a-me look of you behint. Ah! dat is pretty well—Encore! atother side, turn yourself again—He bien! without flattery, men cher Olivier, you have great deal of de bonne grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Zooks! a man shou'd have nothing but bones to be ramm'd into this jacket; I warrant there is not more cloth upon my back than wou'd serve to cover a chrisrening pincushion.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Well, well, be content; 'tis made to shew your shapes.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Very likely: there's nothing thrown away but the labor.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Morbleu! here is milor again—Allons, mon ami, let us be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Too much, too much—by my soul, Jack, I cannot stand it; let me have some breath or I shall burst.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: The old girl swallows the bait glibly, does she not?

SP.SPEAKER: L, Janus.
SP.P: No wonder when you butter it so un∣mercifully; how is it you can keep your countenance?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Ask rather how my countenance keeps me; I owe it many a good turn at a hard pinch, and now methinks 'tis high time to marry and be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Hold there, friend Jack! it we are both to play the same game, he that's first up may chance to spoil the other's hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Content yourself about that and tho' you are Horry Singieton every where e'se you shall be Lord Janus here, and have all your privileges of being first serv'd; then I hope your humble servant may have leave to help himself: Fair Eleanor is the dith of dainties at the head of the table; plain Dorothy is the piece de resistance at the foot of it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Enough said! if that be so I am con∣tent.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Commend me to your modesty for that: 'foregad I think the man that takes dame Dorothy's person will have fairly earned her purfe: sarangle me if I wou'd be plagu'd with her, but that I began to think a little snug retreat would be seasonable, some little property that I may fairly call my own.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: That might prevent mistakes to be sure; if you had property of your own, you need not trouble other people for their's so often as you have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: That's true; hitherto I have only had right of common upon the wide world; marriage is like a bill of enclosure, by which every man has his own lot to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Yes, and he may keep it to himself so long as he can fence out his neighbours; but that is not often the case.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Dorothy will be a good stake in my hedge however; he, that breaks into her pasture, must risque more in the attack, than he can profit by the trespass.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: I confess there is enough to baulk a bolder sportsman than I pretend to be; but keep your eye upon Sir Solomon; he is lord of the manor here, and if nobody claims Dorothy, she and her strong box will fall as an escheat to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: If you will take care of his daughter, I think I may promise to provide for Dorothy, and thus between us we may give him a sine-cure for the rest of his days.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: And when all his caree are over, I will quietly lay down my peerage, retire from the gaieties of the world, and live like a plain country gentleman do this plain country house.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I guess you will prefer it for your summer residence to Janus Castle itself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Yes, I shall put that aside as a jointure-house for my lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Right! we will keep that snug in the red box with the rest of the deeds, which Sir Solomon has taken charge of; if it escapes out of his hands, let him look to the loss; it is not our business to disturb such quiet property.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: But after all what say you to Solomon? is he not a precious fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I like him better than I do that same Cap∣tain Bluff; I don't know what to think of him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Never think about him; those web∣footed fowl are nimble on the water, but mere wad∣dlers upon land.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: And what for a girl is Miss Eleanor the heiress?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P:
A wood-nymph, a hamadryad, light as aether, fresh as air, and altogether, my dear Jack,
so adorably charming, that if I had not such an un∣controulable, inexpressible passion for her fortune, I am apt to think I should be in love with her for her person.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: What are we about then? If we are loyera, let as follow up the fair. Dorothy and I lost ground at the starting, and my old girl is no Atalanta, neither light as aether nor fresh as air, but remember the old fable where the tortoise wi the race from the hare.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: The , with a view of Sir Solomon's House.
Sir CHARLES FREEMANTLE, ELEANOR in her riding habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: NOW I have see you safe upon your eet and you assure me you have got no hurt by your fall, give me leave to say you have had such a escape, as will make it madness if you ever mount the back of vicious animal any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Yes, we call her the vin more; she wou'd have shewn me no mercy if I had hung in my stirrup, and that I must have done if it had not been for you; I shall always believe I owe my life to you

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: And I shall always consider it as the happiest moment of mine, which brought me to your rescue: May I know the lady's name, I have been thus fortune in assisting?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I live at this house which you see; I am the daughter of Sir Solomon Sapient; you are a srnger in these parts I prceive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I am a traveller, and far from my own home, but tho' I am a stranger to you and may never have the happiness of meeting you again▪ yet I hope you will allow me to request one favour of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Pray do, and I'll grant it, be it what it will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
As this adventure has for ever fixt you in my memory, it will be much for my repose in fu∣ture wou'd you give me your faithful promise never
to commit yourself on that vixen mare, as you call her, any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Goodness alive! do you call that a favour? you must be very kind-hearted to be at such concern about me; but at all events I give you my promise, and if you doubt my keeping it let your servant take the mare away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I shou'd put her to death the next mo∣ment, were she mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Bless your heart! our folks only laugh at such accidents; but pray now step into the house and rest yourself after your fatigue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I'm afraid I cannot now avail myself of your politeness.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Politeness! not at all: do now—you might if you wou'd, pray do—never mind your boots; there's no ceremony—Mercy be good unto me! what a pickle I am in! only look what a petticoat I have got.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Come, you are well off to have hurt nothing but your cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Oh! hang my cloaths, they are used to it; I thought at first I had put out my ancle: look what a wrench I have given it! Heyday, what's here to do? will you be so good to put the lacing of my boot to rights? Don't you go to say any thing to papa about my fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Will you conceal it from your fa∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Why, aye to be sure—Heh!—what!—isn't it right? nay, I won't do it, if you think 'tis wrong—Dear! how awkward you go about it; why, that's not the way. Here! I'll shew you; you shou'd pass it through here; now you're right—And so you don't think I should sink this accident on my fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Perhaps I don't think a young lady shou'd sink y thing on her father.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: An, but that—that won't always do though;—wll it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Heavens! this girl bewitches me—(aside.) I shou'd guess you have no secrets you need conceal from your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: That's as much as to say you guess I have no secrets at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Let this little misadventure then stand for one, and when you are at the pains of keeping one, will you consent at my request to keep an∣other?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: By all means; tell it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: This it is then—If I converse with you five minutes longer, I shall be absolutely and irreco∣verably in love with you for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Indeed! well, five minutes are soon gone; don't be in a hurry—Hush! hark! what talking's that? sure I hear my father's voice: stay where you are; don't be afraid—I'll be sure to come back to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES
SP.P: What possesses me? I am fascinated, fixt; spell∣bound by the wand of an enchaess: the place is full of charms, and filtres; she has sprinkled love powder in the air and every breath I draw brings in∣fection to my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: 'Tis my father sure enough. Oh my giddy head, I forgot to ask by what name I am to introduce you to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Freemantle is my name; if you think fit, you may add Sir Charles to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Sir Charles Freemantle—a baronet—I wish you had been a lord—I charge you don't run away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I met your servant with your horses and he says you've had a sall. My dear child, is all well; are you safe and unhurt?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Thanks to this gentleman for saving me, I have receiv'd no manner of hurt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I am infinitely indebted to the gentleman; but I have not the happiness of knowing him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: It is Sir Charles—Sir Charles—Pray, Sir, ell my father your name

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Freemantle is my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Of the county of Kent, good Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I live in Kent, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I know your family full well; a very anti∣ent and respectable house; I have the honor to rank next to you, Sir Charles, upon the roll of baronets. In very truth, Sir, you have restor'd to me the only hopes of my family; if there is any thing Sir Solomon Sapient can do to shew his gratitude and respect to you, I answer to that name, and shall be most happy to approve myself your very humble servant in all ounden duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I am overpaid, Sir Solomon, by my great good fortune in chancing upon this young lady as I was travelling the road, just where her horse begun a plunging; by a sudden spring from the back of mine I caught her in my arms as she was falling, and seiz∣ing hold of her rein at the same time held the mis∣cevous animal fast by the head, till I bad extricated her foot from the stirrup; and now give me leave to remark to you, Sir Solomon, that had I a life so pre∣cious in my charge I shou'd hold myself uardonable, were I to expose it to such danger any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: There, there, Eleanor, you hear what Sir Charles says.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Yes, papa, and I have promis'd to ob∣serve what he says: isn't he very kind to take so much concern about me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I protest and swear I am more bound to you. Sir Charles, than I can find words to express; I pray you, worthy Sir, let me improve the happy moment of our meeting: I think you said you was upon your journey, let me request you will make my humble cottage your inn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I cannot think of waiting upon you in this trim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Oh dear heart, your riding dress is quite sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I told you so at first: How can you be so ceremonious?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: We have other travellers in the same pre∣dicament with yourself; perhaps you may be ac∣quainted with the noble personage, who now honors me with his company; perhaps you know the Lord Viscount Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Intimately, I know him intimately and honor him very highly, as every man, who knows him, must.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Truly he is a very amiable young noble∣man, and I am happy to hear you report so favour∣ably of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Sir, it is not my single voice that can do justice to Lord Janus, the whole world is loud in his praises.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Mind that, daughter Eleanor: He has a very fine fortune I understand—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: That is the least of his recommendati∣ons; he has a very good heart, Sir Solomon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: There again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: An excellent understanding—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he's very acute, in good truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Pardon me, I do not speak of his un∣derstanding in that stile; he is much too modest and well-bred to affect the man of wit and acuteness; he is of the gentlest manners and diffident almost to failing—

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Oh, then I assure you he has effectually god id of that failig.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, child, you don't know what diffidence is.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: If I am to judge of it by Lord Janus, I confess I do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I assure you it is too apt to intercept his good qualities and keep them out of sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Why really, Sir Charles Freemantle, I do not see that failing in Lord Janus in the degree you mention; his lordship has a fluency of expression, a very happy command of his features, a ready address in setting himself off to advantage, as indeed it well becomes him to do; but he makes no display of his fortune, he his above that; no equipage, no suite of servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: That's much indeed; for in general his lordship is very splendid in those respects.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Alas a-day, he has nobody with him but old Philibert the Frenchman, and he looks more like a Jew than any thing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: You surprise me much; I can't think where he has pick'd up such a person: I can remem∣ber he had a very smart fellow in that capacity, one Harry Singleton, a mighty favourite; but as I had no opinion of his honesty I always thought his reign wou'd be a short one

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol
SP.P: Well, Sir Charles, if you will honor me with your company, you will have the pleasure of meeting an old acquaintance, and confer a great favor upon a new one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I must be insensible of my own hap∣piness, cou'd I resist so much politeness: you will give me leave to ride back to my inn, and wait upon you at your hour of dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Use your pleasure, good Sir Charles, at the hour of four we shall expect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Be sure you do not fail us. A thousand, thousand thanks, and till then good bye to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES FREEMANTLE.
SP.P: Farewel! Who shall now tell me love at first sight is but a fable?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Then 'tis agreed to make our grand at∣tack this very day—

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: By all means; there is no time to be lost: I have cook'd up a kind of abstract for your lordship to sign, which you will pass upon Solomon for the sketch of a settlement, and on the strength of this se∣curity press him to let the marriage be consummated out of hand: I think I can answer for the old fool, if you have made your way as well with the young one.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Can you doubt of that? don't you think I make a very gallant appearance? am I not equipt at all points like a lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Yes truly, you are very handsomely meta∣morphos'd by the help of little Moses the French Jew; I see you have him at your back in the shape of a valet de chambre.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Trust him for sticking close to me; he has an interest in looking well to my wardrobe, for 'tis all his own property, and he brushes every coat con∣amore with a fellow-feeling for its future good appear∣ance in Rag-Fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: To say the truth I have some slight traces in my memory of the very suit now upon your lordship's back.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Very likely; I dare say I'm not the first lord that has worn it.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Nor the first lord's valet perhaps, who has made free to borrow it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: I know when I was in that post in Lord Janus's service, I so often wore his cloaths, that I thought it for his honour to wear his name too.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: 'Tis a pity but you could wear his face also.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Why, as he has two by his title, it wou'd be no great robbery if I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: It must be the face that looks backwards then, for 'tis more than probable that is the way you must take your last journey out of life.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: No croaking, dear Jack, let me try the marriage noose first, and if that don't hold, why a man must submit to his destiny.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Aha! Madam Dorothy, are you here? May this be my destiny!
Am I once more so happy? To day my better genius is at work.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Polycarp, if you are begin∣ning again, I'll not be left alone with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Wherein have I offended you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: What! are you not aware that you made downright love to me last time we were together?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Do you call that love? No, Madam, what my heart dictates and my tongue dares not utter, that is love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Positively I must hear no more of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Is he then so formidable a deity, that the very whiff of his wings puts your spirits into a fitter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: It does indeed; my sensibiliy must not be awaken'd for the cruel purpose of making sport for your vanity: I suspect, Mr. Polycarp, you are a ge∣neral lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I thought you rather chided me for being too particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P:
And so I did, for I have dedicated my days to celibacy and retirement; I do not wish to have the tranquillity of my heart disturb'd, and really
you assail'd it so warmly, that unless you promise me to desist, I must peremptoily fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Don't fly, for pity's sake don't fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Restrain yourself then; suppress these emotions, and I will consent to stay with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Any thing, most amiable of women, so you will not fly; the rigour of your commands shall con∣demn me to silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Don't call it rigour; think not I adhere so scrupulously to decorum as to forbid those delicate attentions, which are so becoming in your sex and so pleasing to our's.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc
SP.P: What can I say when you tell me you have devoted your days to perpetual celibacy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Dor.
SP.P: Did I tell you that, and do you always take a lad at her word on such occasions?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Thus then upon my knees let me adore—

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Oh lud-a-mercy! I beg pardon for my boldness!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: mpertinens fellow▪

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: As I am a sinful man I did not know the gentleman was at his prayers. Good Sir, go on with your devotions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: How often must you be told not to burst into a lady's room in such a manner? Why didn't you tap at the door before you enter'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Dear heart, why didn't you bolt it, and then I cou'd not have enter'd at all?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Dor.
SP.P: What is your busness here?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Only to tell you his worship desires to see you; but I will go back and say you are a little busy at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Come, come, honest Oliver, you seem a man of more discretion than to say any thing about the matter; you know the servant's proverb, He that keeps a secret, makes a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Oh, as for that, let me alone for a secret: Madam Dorothy knows well enough what I can do in that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Well, well, go and tell your master I am coming: say nothing of Mr. Polycarp's being with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: No, no, there is nobody with you; you are quite alone: but I hope the gentleman can remem∣ber to return back to the place he left off at.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: You see what you expose me to: I de∣sire, Sir, you will leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Tell me only when I may be so blest again; where shall we meet?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Why will you be so pressing? can't I take my usual walk in the lime-tree grove, without your following me?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Certainly not, and love tho' blind shall conduct me to the place; groves are propitious to the lover's hopes; there you will listen to my vows; there I shall not kneel in vain; there in my fancy I behold you soften'd by my supplication, pitying, relenting, yielding—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Oh lud! don't talk of yielding: I wonder what you see in me to encourage these rap∣tures.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: What do I see? the majesty of Juno, when you move; the wisdom of Mineva, when you speak; in your eyes the smile of Venus, and about your lips a thousand playful Cupids, which I will seize upon the spot and crush the little wanton rascals—thus and thus—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Mr. Polycarp!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Ah murder!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P:
Release those little wanton Cupids and let
me have a word with 'em before you crush 'em quite to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Very good, very good, Sir Solomon! very pleasant i'faith!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Yes indeed, so it should seem: Cousin Dorothy. I hope you like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Dor.
SP.P: Pooh! don't be foolish: 'Tis none of my doing; isn't there a wedding going forward in the family?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I shou'd suppose so, as I see you have put it into rehearsal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: The gentleman was only giving me joy—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And you was only taking it.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: If it is at all improper for the friends of the contracting parties to welcome such good tidings with a salute, it was my joy upon the occasion that over∣power'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And wasn't you overpowered too, cousin? But pr'ythee now run to daughter Eleanor; she has had a fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dol.
SP.P: A fall! Oh heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol
SP.P: Don't be alarmed, she's not hurt; a gen∣tleman luckily stept in upon the moment and sav'd her; it might have been your case, if I had not stept in as luckily just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Ridiculous! provoking!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol
SP.P: Mr. Polycarp!

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Sir Solomon!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: When I parted from you to go in search of my daughter, I left you in th library engag'd with a book; if I mistke not, you was turning over a page of Tully's Offices.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Nothing more likely; I believe it was that very book.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And if it is not impertinent which of his four cardinal virues might you be engag'd with, whilst you was turning over a page with cousin Dorothy?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P:
'Twou'd be harder to tell you which of the
virtues I was not engaged with, when I had the whole volume in my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: It is a volume let me tell you, that has lain a pretty many years on the shelf, and you will find a pretty many crabbed pages in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Beauty, Sir Solomon, is the fairest page in the manuscript of the creation; a scholar seeks for what he may admire in it; a booby looks about for what he may find fault with: one feeds like a bee upon blossoms, the other like a beetle upon dirt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Under favour I conceive my cousin is not very beautiful, nor yet very young.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Certainly she is neither, and yet there is a something, give me leave to say, a kind of je'n scais uois about her—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Perhaps you mean her fortune; there in∣deed she has some temptations.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Not for me, not for me; I despise fortune; riches are my contempt, therefore with your leave we will drop the subject, and apply to something more immediate: You must know, Sir Solomon, I have sketcht out an abstract of his lordship's propos'd set∣tlement upon your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: That's well done, Mr. Polycarp; that is very much to the purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: 'Tis noble, 'tis magnificent; perhaps I thought it so in the extreme, but I acted from duty, be from generosity, and so it stands without retrench∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: My deposit with my daughter is 20,000 l. in and, and the residue at my death without heis.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I know it is, and shall be glad to see the transaction clos'd between his lordship and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Have you any doubt then of his standing to his engagement?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P:
Far be it from me to say that, but I have seen one marriage settlement broke off from the dila∣tory proceedings of the lawyers: Lord Janus is a young man; his passions are warm, and 'tis the nature of such tempers to be a little volatile: Were in your case I
shou'd not let him out of my sight; I should marry him on the spot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: How can that be done with security to the parties?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Very easily; let him sign the abstract I have prepared, which effectually binds him to the settlement, and pay you the 20,000 l. into his hands, and the af∣fair is done: The marriage takes place immediately, and your daughter is the Lady Viscountess Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And are you sure his lordship's signing that abstract is good security for the settlement?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I am sure it is as good as any settlement he can make, or any security you can have, tho' his whole estate were bound to make it good: I am your friend, Sir Solomon, in this business: I am indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: My dear Mr. Polycarp, I am everlastingly bound to you: my money is forthcoming, if he is but as ready on his part.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Oh! I will be answerable for him: But how stands the young lady's inclinations all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol
SP.P: And how shou'd you suppose a young lady's inclinations likely to stand from the sample you have had in this family of an old one's?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Ah, Sir Solomon, you're a wag. No more of that if you love me.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir SOLOMON SAPIENT, Lord JANUS. POLYCARP.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir SOLOMON.
SP.P: WELL, my Lord Janus, these are very generous proposals; I cannot hesitate about them; I only doubt if Janus Castle will not be too expensive an establishment for a jointure house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: 'Tis a substantial edifice, and in good repair; I can't complain of my expences in keeping it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I should wonder if you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I have heard much of its magnificence, and I confess my expectations run very high.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Your disappointment will soon overtake 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: But it is not the splendor of your lordship's alliance, which dazzles my ambition; 'tis from the virtue of your character I derive my felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: You hear that, my lord; little does Sir So∣lomon value your nobility, birth and fortune—and in∣deed what are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Aye, what indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I don't say that, my lord; I would not be thought to undervalue worldly enjoyments, nor out∣ward appearances: but I look into the interior of a man; I study the character, that is my habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: A gift, Si Solomon, a gift!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: It is so, Mr. Polycarp, it is so—And now, my Lord Janus, as we have put the business so far in train, I presume I may account myself secure of the honor of calling you my son-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P:
Honor, my good Sir Solomon, is the
very oath and bond of a peer; I must forfeit my title before I can falsify my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I rather think you'll do both at the same time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Now then I may announce my happiness, and open my doors to my friends and neighbours.—Apropos to that, my lord; I chanc'd upon a friend of your's this morning, a gentleman I am under great obligations to for rescuing my daughter from her dan∣ger; a very warm admirer of your lordship, I can as∣sure you; one who speaks of you in raptures.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Aye, indeed! Who may he be?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Sir Charles Freemantle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: The devil it is! Sir Charles Freeman∣tle!—Polycarp, I'm in an ague fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Bless me, Lord Janus! what is the matter? you seem startled.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: What are you about? recollect yourself—[Apart to Lord Janus.] 'Tis his sensibility on the lady's account throw him into these terrors.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Polycarp can witness what a shock it gave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, he has not recover'd himself yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: And therefore to Sir Charles Freemantle, who was the lucky instrument of saving her, we owe the more; I thought I could not do a more acceptable thing to your lordship than give you an opportunity of telling him so. He dines with us to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: O yes; I took upon me to say you would be happy to see him at dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: You said so, did you! You made use of my name to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I did, I did, my lord! I said every thing in your name that was civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: I am oblig'd to you.—Mr. Polycarp, you will return me that settlement; 'tis of no present use; I can do no business to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: How so, how so? What's the matter, I beseech you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible to think of it; all my joys are frustrated, disappointment blasts my ardor; this day, this very day, and none other, had I set down for the consummation of my happiness; love fir'd my heart; generosity expanded it: the deed was ready, the very pen was in my fingers, that was to portion my bride, when suddenly my evil genius steps in, and the vision vanishes into air.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I told you how it would be; I warn'd you of the turn he wou'd take: he'll be off; he will, upon my soul—If not, I can answer for one that will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: What do you tell me? Off! will he be off? sure you are not in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janue.
SP.P: Sir Charles Freemantle is a person I cannot be in company with.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: No, indeed, your lordship and Sir Charles must not meet—at least I will not be present at the in∣terview.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Why, what can all this mean? If there is truth in man, I never heard one gentleman speak of another in more kind and friendly terms.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: An please your worship, Sir Charles Free∣mantle is arriv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: There, there, there! what's to be done now?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Where would you please to have him shewn?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Not into this room, for your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Hold, hold! who's in the drawing-room?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Nobody but Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Shew him in there: say that I will come to him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P:
What the murrain ails 'em now? Ah my poor master, thou hast stust thy skull so full of my
lord, that thou hast turn'd out thy wits to make room for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: My Lord Janus, I am quite confounded at what has happen'd; I had no intention of inviting any person disagreeable to your lordship; but what am I to do, now the gentleman is in my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Get him out of it as speedily as you can, Sir Solomon, if my longer stay in it is of any consequence to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Upon what pretence shall I turn him thus abruptly out of my house? Has he any design upon your lordship? Is he unfit company for a gentleman? is he other than he pretend to be; a cheat, an im∣postor?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: He has been pleas'd to describe my character to you in very handsome terms: I shall not speak of his; I shall say no more of Sir Charles Free∣mantle, than that I know him only too well; and that if he is to be admitted into your house, I must positively quit it.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I can only assure you, Sir Solomon, that his lordship has the best reasons in the world for what he says; a person of Lord Janus's character will be very properly delicate about entering into particulars; you must not expect it from him: but if you set any value upon his alliance, I can tell you it is no otherwise to be obtained but by disinissing your visitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: No doubt, no doubt, I will, Mr. Polycarp—but how?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Nothing so easy; 'tis done every day: a ci∣vil apology on the score of health, or business, or sud∣den engagement—any thing of the sort will serve for an excuse to get rid of an unwelcome guest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Very true: I'll instantly set about it; and if I can find brother George, I'll send him upon the errand.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Lord Janus, I am your lordship's obedi∣ent: I shall move off, whilst my legs are at liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: How now, my master! where am I to be, if you take the bitt in your teeth and are off?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: And where shall I be, when your sham∣lordship is detected and blown up?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Jack, I am such a friend o good-fellowship, that if it were only to enjoy of a horse-pond, I should be glad to have you with me: How shall I support my melancho∣ly mlitations in the stocks, unless I have the conso∣lation of seeing you fast lockt by my side?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I am obliged to you; you have a pleasant easy way of providing for your friends. In the name of folly, why did I, a novice in iniquity, join stock with one of so establish'd a fame, that even in this odd corner of the island we can't enjoy a little season∣able obscurity?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus
SP.P: Come, come, I have more resources than you dream of.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Methinks you were cruelly puzzled to turn to them; I never saw a fellow in a worse plunge, and had not I help'd you out, I know not what wou'd have become of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Well, well; let us retire to my cham∣ber and keep out of sight till Sir Charles is gone, and then we shall have a clear field for action. Come along.
SP.STAGE: Sir CHARLES FREEMANTLE, followed by ELEANOR.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Where are you going? what is it that dif∣turbs you? are you afraid of being left alone with me till my father comes?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I am indeed; every moment grows more painful than another.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Why? What have I said or done to give you pain?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Come, come, you know the nature of the pain you give me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I know I am very little qualified to enter∣tain you, but I can answer from my heart that I never meant to offend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Offend me? No. Must I then plainly tell you, that you are too charming and I too sensible to your charms?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Nay, if you run away from me only be∣cause you like me, I must suppose it is for instruction sake, to teach me what I ought to do towards you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: This is cruel kindness, for you are flattering my passion when you should be assisting me to fly from it: you may now return the little service I have done you; we have chang'd situations since the morning; I am now in the danger; reach out your and and save me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Here is my hand: What can I offer more? take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Can I take the property of another? can I defraud a friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Ah! now I understand your scruples; you suppose my father has engaged me to Lord Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: 'Tis true, and as I love the man, and know his merit, I cannot think of interfering with pre∣tensions, not only prior but superior to my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Very well, I see what you point at; you told me I was to keep no secrets from my father; I am to have no preference, no choice nor will of my own. What if I don't like Lord Janus, I to be forc'd to marry him against my inclinations?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: How shall I answer that question and not appear like a seducer? let your own heart answer it: if you do not like Lord Janus, I can only say the most admir'd young man in the kingdom is not to your taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Indeed he is not, and I could be glad you would tell me for which of his lordship's superior good qualities I ought to hold him in such admiration.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
That would be a little too hard upon
me; I will do him justice as a man of honor, but I will not undertake his cause as an advocate.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: And did you do him justice a while ago, when you told us he was diffident almost to a failing? there I think I may venture to defend his character, tho' I am as little inclin'd to be his advocate as you can be. You told us at the same time he had a good heart and an excellent understanding—'tis a pity such perfection should be lost upon me. You said that he was modest, well-bred, and of the gentlest manners—these are charming qualities; convince me only that his lordship possesses them, and I cannot chuse but admire him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Fie upon you, lovely but betwitching temper, you have rifled me of my heart, and now you wou'd rally me out of my reason: but I'll not be trapp'd into any such undertaking as you propose: I shall leave Lord Janus to his own defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Nay, but stay a moment, and hear how easily it is done; stand only in that place for your friend, and see how instantly you will make a convert of me; nay, but keep your post, for now I acknow∣ledge all the virtues you have ascrib'd to him, now I contemplate every thing, which I regard as worthy to be admir'd and lov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Oh heaven and earth! what transports I shou'd now enjoy, if I dar'd but to indulge them; but I must escape with honor whilst I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: So you will go; Ah I then I see my er∣ror, and diffidence is indeed the failing you describ'd.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir Charles Freemantle, I must beg leave to introduce myself to you as the uncle of this young lady, and as such to assure you I shall ever retain a grateful sense of the very important service you ren∣dered her this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
The interest you take in that happy event, captain, makes it doubly pleasing to me, for
I hope I am too good an Englishman not to reverence the character of so brave an officer, as I have now the honor to take by the hand.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Alas, sir, my small services merit no such encomiums;—but, Sir Charles, I have a few words in commission from my brother, and, with my niece's Jeave, I would deliver them to you in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Very well, uncle George, I will do is you bid me; I will go and leave you to yourselves—but I am sorry it must be a secret, because I am sure, if you had any thing to say that wou'd make me hap∣py, you wou'd not send me out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: If I understood my niece rightly, Sir Charles, you have discovered the situation of things in this family, and are doing that from your own dell∣cacy, which wou'd else seem a breach of hospitality to suggest to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: 'Tis very true, Sir; I apprehend there is business going for ward in this family, that wou'd make my company very unreasonable, and, if I am right in my conjecture, why shou'd I put you to the pain of an apology?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir Charles, you have candidly excus'd me from the most awkward service I was ever engaged in: the truth is, my brother and Lord Janus are just now very seriously employed; his lordship's lawyer is come from town for the purpose; and I understand the affair to be of such a nature, as not to allow of those attentions, which, in any other circumstances, they would be proud to pay you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I certainly shall not think of Inter∣rupting any parties so engag'd; but I flatter myself that, to a gentleman of your character, I may speak openly and ingenuously what occurs to me on this occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: By all means, sir; use no reserve with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
Then I must say to you in confidence, that I suspect my friend Lord Janus will meet more
difficulties than he seems to be aware of; and I am perswaded he is the last man living to press forward a treaty with the lady's father, unless he thought him∣self secure of her affections.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: It may be so, but these are matters out of my line, which I never meddle in: I love my niece, and wish to see her happy, but I have no voice in the disposal of her, nor am I in the secret of her in clinati∣ons.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Misunderstand me not, I pray you; I am not sounding you on the subject of her inclinations, I am only guarding against those consequences, which may ensue upon the presumption of Lord Janus's dis∣appointment: I know him well, a nobler gentleman does not live, nor is there a family in the kingdom but might well be proud of his alliance.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: This is a very honourable testimony on your part, Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: It is but justice; and if a certain acci∣dent, which happen'd this morning, may have left impressions on your niece's mind in favour of an ob∣ject, whose pretensions cannot vie with those of Lord Janus, it becomes a very serious point with me to clear myself from all suspicion of such mean clandestine mea∣sures, as one competitor will sometimes enviously practise to degrade and level his superior; as Lord Ja∣nus is my particular friend, I must therefore insist upon an interview with him before I leave the place.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I commend you for your caution, and 'tis what you have a right to expect; but as he is now in the very act of signing and sealing with my brother, I think you will not press for it immediately, nor per∣haps consider this house as the properest place for your meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I would not wish to remain in this house, where my longer stay might subject me to suspicions, I have already made some sacrifices to avoid; I had rather meet Lord Janus any where else.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Didn't you notice a little rustic building in the wood, as you came down the avenue to the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I did; there cannot be a fitter ren∣dezvous; I'll order my chaise to follow me, and beg you to tell Lord Janus I will wait for him there.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I will certainly do it, and shall hold myself bound on all occasions to bear witness to your very honourable proceedings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I cannot wish a better advocate. Good day to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Uncle George!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, my dear, what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: So you're alone, I find: your visitor is gone; heighol we have seen the last of him.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Are you particularly concern'd for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I'll put a case to you in your own way, and then you shall judge if I have not reason to be con∣cern'd—but you'll answer fairly?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: To be sure I will; let me hear your case, my pretty Eleanor.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Why suppose now your ship had struck upon a rock, and you and it were perishing in the waves; and suppose a gallant generous fellow was in that very moment of distress to save your life at the risque of his own—shoudn't you be very much obliged to him?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Undoubtedly I should; what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Why then how can you wonder if what would be obligation in your case, should be love in mine?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Ah, you subtle hussey! I must not be en∣tangled by you in this manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: But is he not a noble fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, well! put no leading questions to m I'm not a match for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I hope you don't compare my lord to him for person.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I am no critic in men's persons.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: No, no; I dare say you look to the good qualities of a man; to his courage, to his honestry, for instance.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, child, and is not honesty a recom∣mendation in every man's character?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Oh, yes, if he was an attorney, a very great one; but let me ask you, uncle George—was you ever in love?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Go, you idle thing you, what a question's that!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Did you ever fail in love with a girl, who had nothing else to recommend her but honesty? Not you. Love himself is a thief, you know; and let Sir Charles say what fine things he will of Lord Janus, he only sets himself in a better light with me, and throws his friend to a further distance.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Come, come, this is mere raillery and idle talking; I flatter myself you don't intend to disap∣point your father's wishes, by refusing the great match he has provided for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: And if I did, coudn't I supply the place of it with one as good? I am not over-ambitious of a great title; a baronet's lady will serve my turn.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You cannot doubt Lord Janus's morit, when his very rival speaks so highly of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Oh dear heart! Lord Janus may have all the merit in the world, and yet my Lady Janus be a very miserable woman. But tell me what you have done with Sir Charles, and where you have dispos'd of him: I hope he's coming here again.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: That can hardly be expected.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Will he go without speaking to Lord Janus?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P:
Perhaps not; they may converse together, and yet not make this house their place of meeting:
and this reminds me that I have a message in charge, which I must make haste and deliver. Adieu?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Fairest object in nature, how blest am I in being privileg'd to address you as your be∣troth'd admirer! Your worthy father has admitted me to an assiance, which will add a lustre to the brightest henors of my family, and I wait the approaching mo∣ment, that is to make us one, with an ardo nothing but the warmest passion can inspire.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: As my father has assured your lordship of my compliance, I hope he can answer for my happi∣ness too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Oh, my angel? when I have the rapturous delight to call you mine, you will only have to command, and be obeyed; to wish, and to be gratified in all you wish: for my fortune, I'll not speak of it; all is your's, I possess nothing: for my title, think it only borrowed to adorn you; I shall covet no other honor but that of being the most fa∣vour'd of your slaves.

SP.SPEAKER: Fleanor.
SP.P: Be assured, my lord, my endeavours shall not be wanting to set you at liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: If you see me here a private man, un∣furnished, unattended, 'tis that I may dazzel you the more when I present you to the admiring world one gem of lustre, splendid as your own brilliant charms; equipage, attendants, pleasures, palaces, are at your feet, and court you to enjoy them.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Indeed! I protest this is a very amusing inventory, and shews how well you understand to chuse out playthings for a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Foregad! I must change my attack; this will never do.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P:
Pray go on, for as yet there is no one thing in your catalogue I wish to bid for, not an ar∣ticle
for which I would barter the freedom of my con∣dition and sacrifice the affections of my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: She has fairly put me down; I have not a word to say for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Believe me, Lord Janus, you have made a small mistake in supposing I am to fall in love with the world by description: when I enter upon it, I hope to take a friend for my guide, whom I can love and trust; one who will teach me rather how to shun it's temptations than be himself the tempter: as your lord∣ship therefore has only paid your addresses to my va∣nity, my vanity is very much at your service; my heart I shall otherwise dispose of.

SP.SPEAKER: L Janus.
SP.P: Now for my last effort.—Most charming of your sex, it is your heart I aspire to; it is that heavenly grace, those killing eyes, that lovely form—Oh! let me clasp it in my longing arms!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor
SP.P: Stand off! Are you the elegant, the ac∣complished Lord Janus, whom your friend Sir Charles describes in aptures?

SP.SPEAKER: L Janus.
SP.P: No truly I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: The modest, well-bred, gentle peer, whose diffidence is his only failing?—I'll not believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: L Janus.
SP.P: Upon my soul, you are much in the right of it. [aside]—O generous beauty, pardon this extravagance of my passion; it's raptures overpower'd me: how shall I attone for this involuntary offence?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I'll tell you how, my lord—Go to your friend Sir Charles Freemantle, find him out and either convince him that he has mistaken you, or by copying his manners learn to make yourself more acceptable to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord JANUS.
SP.P: 'Tis all up with me: I can act the lord, but I can∣not counterfeit the lover: this pedlar's courtship has undone me; I must ev'n give it in, strip off this fool's jacket, and decamp.

SP.SPEAKER: POLYCARP.
SP.P: HEYDEY! what's in the wind now? you have slipt your skin.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: And in good time, or it had been too hot to hold me.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: But what's the matter after all?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: This girl won't hear reason and I can't make love; that consounded Sir Charles Freemantle is still lurking about.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Why then I must either clear the ground of him, or he of me: I am going to meet him.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Completely so, with him, with her, with fortune, all the world—I am at my last prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Your first I rather think, if at any.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: The fellow stipulates for an inter∣view; he is waiting for me at a rendezvous in the wood; these people insist upon my seeing him; the captain was charg'd with a message to me; Sir Solo∣mon still engages for his daughter, if I can drive this lurking lover out of her way.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: And do you undertake for that?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: You see I am arm'd for the attempt; prepar'd either for engagement or retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P:
Can't you comprehend that in this un∣dress I am Harry Singleton and Lord Janus's valet de chambre, a character I am more perfect in than that
of his lordship? Well then—I make up a story for the purpose; nobody is present at our meeting, and as he does not know I have quitted my service, he believes what I rell him, and I bolt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Do you so of a certain? suppose he will not be bolted.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Then I know who will.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: And what's to be done with me?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: You must shift for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Is that your care of me?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Nay, man, don't be angry: you have still a good game in hand, if Dorothy's eyes tell truth; follow up your fortune there; when I am gone, the field will be open; Sir Solomon will be outrageous against his daughter and caress you in hopes of making up matters with me: All this you can manage to your own purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Well, well, I own this carries some face: Dorothy is no small prize either in bulk or ballast; she's full of ingots.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Now then, Jack, give me your hand, perhaps for the last time: Do we part friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Cordially.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Then fare thee well, my hearty fellow, if so it shall be? And may that slippery slut Fortune, tho' she jilts me, prove staunch to thee; therefore a thou wou'd'st have shar'd in my success, had it pleas'd her infernal divinity to grant it, so let me participate in thine, if in her celestial graces she shall smile up∣on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Then here's my hand! and with it my promise that if ever this fame hand takes possession of Dame Dorothy's strong box, there shall be a nest-egg lest at the bottom for an unlucky friend to brood upon.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: That's honest, and I thank thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P:
And now, as we are upon parting, I'll give thee a proof, that, tho' I have not known thee long, I know thee well. Thou hast every quality of a gen∣tleman about thee, but the principles of one; birth, that shou'd not have been disgrac'd; education, that
ought not to have been abus'd; and talents, which it is a scandal to pervest; had you applied them as you ought, instead of sinking into the menial drudgery of service, you might have rais'd yourself to a level with that station, which you treacherously counterfeit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: The devil himself will turn moralist, if you begin a preaching; therefore no more, but be∣take yourself to your Dorothy; if my string fails, I shall away to the next inn, there consign myself to the basket of some charitable stage, where I shall sit like the real Janus, with a melancholy face looking back∣wards on the world, and meditating on the quick transitions of all human grandeur.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Sol.
SP.P: Didn't I see Lord Janus leave the room just now?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Yes, and I'm afraid he will leave the house before long; he does not find that promising return of affection in your daughter, of which you spoke so confidently; she seems very old to his addresses

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: A good token, Mr. Polycarp, a special good token; 'tis a way she has; it runs in her family; when I courted her mother, she was for all the world like Eleanor; you would have sworn she cou'd not bear the sight of me; she wou'd run away and hide herself, if she did but hear the very sound of my foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Aye indeed! that's much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I tell you truth, she wou'd wring her hands and cry and take on at such a rate, if I offer'd to make suit to her—

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Some people wou'd have taken that for aversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P:
They wou'd so, they wou'd so; but I knew better, I knew the ways of women and that a tear upon the cheek is no more a sign of sorrow than a molo upon the skin—Lord love you! there was
more blubbering at my wedding than ever was be∣stowed upon a funeral.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Than you perhaps bestow'd upon her lady∣ship's—but I hope you made her happy whilst you liv'd together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Happy, Mr. Polycarp! I made her amaz∣ingly happy; happy to a proverb; we were call'd, The Turtles: maiden tears are as sure a prelude to married happiness, as spring showers to summer fruits—and so my lord will find—but your servant; I have no time to spare; I shall go and give my Miss a lec∣ture: Mr. Polycarp, your servant—Look, look! here comes cousin Dorothy—Hands off there, if you love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Oh sie, Sir Solomon! don't suspect me—Go, go! bring your daughter to a proper way of thinking, and I'll take care of your cousie.
Oh! heavens, she comes, and smiling comes—Love in her eyes fits playing, and sheds delicious death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Nonsense! there will be anger in my eyes, if you pesist to flatter me; you know I hate flat∣tery; I can't bear raptures; teach 'em to your lord; he may address them to a younger and a faires ob∣ject.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Let him, if he prefers the rising to the me∣ridian sun; let him worship the pale quivering beam, that faintly glimmers in the twilight of the morn, let me enjoy the vertical full blaze, a glowing canopy of warmth and splendor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Raptures again! you men of genius deal in nothing else; but are they lasting, are they true?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Ovid was not a truer votary to love than I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor
SP.P: Aye, you are a scholar, there's another danger; I shou'd be jealous even of your books; grant I had nothing to fear from living rivals, how shou'd I be secur'd from dead ones?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Then welcome, beauty, and adieu to books! we will consign them all to oblivion but one; and that I will reserve for you alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Indeed! and which is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: The Manual of Love; none but a scholar can develope the sublime philosophy of the tender pas∣sion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Passion and philosophy! how do they agree? I thought there had been no philosophy in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Pardon me, how else shou'd I keep my pas∣sion within bounds, how support life itself without possessing that for which alone I live?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: A true lover will live a long while upon hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Then it must not be that meagre moon-shine diet, which poor Lord Janus is fed with; it must not be that maw kish greensick hope that tantalizes his ap∣petite: a few hours perhaps, a day or two at most I can live upon it, but fix a certain time, an early mo∣ment for my happiness, or expect to see me pine away into an atrophe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Well then perhaps—but take notice I'll not be hurried—perhaps I may consent to give you hopes, if I find you in the same mind a twelvemonth hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Twelvemonths, my charmer! do you take me for a patriarch? twelve days would be an insup∣portable period.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Oh frightful! what wou'd the world say were I to take so rash a step?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: To-morrow let it be; nay, why not this very day?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Dor.
SP.P: Bless me, this very day! you hurry me out of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: No, loveliest of women, I wou'd rather hurry you into your happiness; let this languid couple crawl there own dreaming pace, but let us fly to the goal and seize the prize before them. Give me your hand, remember you promis'd me a walk in the grove; there we may converse at our ease and secure from in∣terruption: Come! I have much to say to you and many arguments to move you to compliance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Well then I'll go upon condition you re∣frain from raptures.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I'll do my best to obey you; but if my passi∣on breaks bounds, recollect your own maxim. That there is no philosophy in love.

O Fortune, if thou art indeed a goddess, prove, thyself a good-natur'd one by taking pity on a poor fellow at a hard pinch, who is one of thy broken re∣tainer, and wou'd fain make it up with thee for all the foul tricks thou hast play'd me in time past, and the many thousand curses I have bestow'd upon thee in return. Now, now stand my friend! for here comes y man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: Harry Singleton!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: The same at your honor's service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: You live with Lord Janus still▪

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus,
SP.P: My lord is much too good a master for me to quit, and too easily pleas'd with my poor ser∣vices to dismiss me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: And is he coming? Does he know I am waiting for him?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: He knows it full well; the Captain de∣liver'd your message, and these are the words I have in charge to say to you—“Go to Sir Charles Free∣mantle,” says he, “and tell him that I feel all possible gratitude for the handsome things he has said of me to the lady of my heart, and for his very honorable conduct in forbearing to pursue the ad∣vantages, which a looky rencontre with that lady this morning seem'd to have given him.”

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I am very glad his lordship saw my conduct in that light: Go on.

P.Q: "Tell him," says he, “that I am now happy enough to have conquered the impressions, which that accident seem'd to make, and find my∣self perfectly reinstated in the good graces of my charmer; that she has consented to make me hap∣py, and we are now settling the deeds and appoint∣ing the day of our nuptials.”

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: You surprise me; is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Even so, upon my vercity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I never cou'd have suspected it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Why not, Sir? perhaps you do not know the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: It seems I do not: if this be so, she must be the arrantest coquette in nature.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Oh dear Sir, woe beide the man that marries her! Nobody can tell the pains I have taken with my lord to draw him off, but it was his fate, and you may bless your stars, Sir Charles, for the es∣cape you have had.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: By my soul, Harry, I bgin to think so.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: With great reason let me assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
Damnation I but it vees me to have
been so deceiv'd in a girl of her sort, a child, a mere baby, all nature and simplicity as it seem'd.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Very true, Sir Charles, but all men are liable to be deceived—I hope you at least will not prove an exception.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Let me perish but it were a friendly act to open his eyes; I'll go to Lord Janus, and de∣mand an interview.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: No, no, Sir; I beseech you not to think of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Why not? 'tis due to honour, friend∣ship, justice; shall I see my friend upon the brink of ruin, and not rouse him to a sense of his danger?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Alas-a-day, Sir, I have done all that over and over again, but it is too late; it is impossible to prevent it; nay, if it were possible, give me leave to say it were improper to prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: How so? how can it be improper?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Because—but I beg your pardon, Sir, I ought not to reveal secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
