SP.P: What is it you mean? explain your∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Good Sir, don't compel me to do that: it is not fit to be explained: you have had an escape, that is enough; believe me, Sir Charles Freemantle, you have had an escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: Has my lord taken earnest of her fa∣vours? is she a wanton?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: It does not become me to say what she is▪ 'tis an affair of honor, Sir Charles; you will in∣tepret for yourself; you now see the reason why my lord declin'd a meeting with you; he cannot enter into explanations with you, you cannot wish to enter into rivalship with him; you have a happy rid∣dance and no doubt will slip your cable and be off.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Off! to be sure I will—Wou'd to heaven he could be off too!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Honor, Sir Charles, honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: 'Sblood, man, what tell you me of honor? 'tis ruin, misery and inevitable disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: I hope, Sir Charles, you will consider a poor servant and not betray me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Pr'ythee don't suspect me for a tatler, that is not my character: if I cou'd render him any service I wou'd, but that being impossible, step back to your lord, and tell him that I leave him my good wishes and am hurrying out of the country as fast as my horses can carry me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: I'll be sure to give him your very words—Any further commands, Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Stay! let me reflect—If you have an opportunity of speaking privately to the lady—but no matter; let that pass; deliver what I told you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: To a syllable—(Oh! you are a precious gull!) A good journey to your honor: I see your chaise is waiting—I heartily wish your honor all health and happiness and a pleasant tour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Enough, enough. Good bye to you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: I humbly take my leave—A fair wind to your small cargo of wits—Fortune, I acquit thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES
SP.P: How have I been deceiv'd in this young hypocrite! A more artless innocent creature I thought I had never seen—The hussy! to throw out her alurements to me—Poor Janus, how I pity thee! she would have made me believe he was her aversion: the world, it must be own'd, corrupts some women; this woman is born for retaliation, and will corrupt the world—But as I live here she comes!—Oh, thou deluding mischief —how like an innocent she looks—So, so, she pre∣tends not to see me: pretty affectation!—now sor sham start, an engaging flutter—(During this latter part Eleanor enters, deep in thought.) Meditating, fair lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Ah! Sir Charles Freemantle?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Marriage is a copious subject for re∣flection, especially in your case, where it promises so many delights.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: So many! which are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: In the first place novelty, which you'll allow is a very delightful thing, in the next variety, more delightful still, pleasures in abundance, admirers without number, coquetry without bounds—

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Oh fie upon you! you give a worse pic∣ture of matrimony than Lord Janus himself did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: How did he describe it to you? logi∣cally or experimentally?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I don't know what you mean by that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: By words or by actions?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: By both; but his words were so foolish and his actions so impertinent, that he fairly put me out of conceit with it and I determin'd to have nothing more to say to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: You dismiss'd him upon proof—?

SP.SPEAKER: Elanor.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Upon my word, young Madam, you have a most happy assurance.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: By the same token I have a quarrel with you for giving him a character to me, which he in no one respect deserves: you told me he was modest, sensi∣ble, polite, diffident to a fault—I find him vain, ridi∣culous, ill-bred and forward in the extreme.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: And do you quarrel with him for such trifles?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Trifles do you call them? Sure, Sir Charles, you change your language with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Ought I not to call them trifles, when in the first place I do not admit them to exist in my friend? in the next place when I am convinc'd that, whether they exist or not, you are determin'd upon marrying him, and that immediately?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: And who has given you this convincing intelligence? Lord Janus himself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Come, come, be more ingenuous; you know it is so, you know it must be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: My father indeed may say it must be so, but I did not expect to be told it by Sir Charles Free∣mantle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Put no more artifices, fair deceiver, upon Sir Charles Freemantle; he is quitting you thïs very moment, for believe me he does not aspire to be the rival of his friend, nor is he over-envious of any happiness that awaits him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: When you charge me with artifice, I am sure there has been some malice employ'd against me, and I make no doubt Lord Janus is the author of it; but when you retort upon me for those unguarded ad∣vances, which prove me only too void of artifice, I can reconcile your treatment of me neither to justice nor humanity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: If I seem to deal unjustly, Madam, 'tis from the error I was in, when I thought you was the very child of nature, all simplicity and truth; when your danger awaken'd my sensibility and your charms sunk deep into my heart: yet even in that moment of my dotage I had fortitude to withstand your allure∣ments, when I found another in possession of your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor
SP.P: My heart! Lord Janus never had an in∣terest in my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Well! perhaps not, let that pass—but do you mean to assert he was never encourag'd to be∣lieve he had that interest?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I can truly assert it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: What, never once in favor with you? not one kind moment, not one glorious golden oppor∣tunity?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Oh Sir Charles, Sir Charles, what can have tempted you to this cruel, this ungenerous treat∣ment of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: She weeps! Guilty, upon my honor!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: How have I deserv'd it of you? Wou'd to heaven I had never seen you, tho' I had met my death instead!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: How is this, Sir Charles Freemantle? I doubt you have broken faith with me: this is one more meeting than I bargain'd for.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: It is one more, Sir, than I wish'd for.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: In tears, my Eleanor? what has afflicted you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Nothing, 'tis no matter; let us return to the house.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I shall not leave this spot 'till I know the cause of your disorder: Have you receiv'd an insult?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: None, but what (thank heaven) I have the spirit to despise.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Go home, my dear, I'll follow you—.And now, Sir Charles, for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: Well, Sir, and what for me?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Correction, vengeance—if you have dar'd to insult the feelings of that lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I am arm'd, Sir; if you chose to give your sword an airing, please yourself; I shall obey your motions in mere complaisance to your humour, for really I don't know any cause of quarrel between you and me.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I'm not a man to quarrel with∣out cause; I came hither understanding you was to have a meeting with Lord Janus, and I came not upon curious but friendly motives, to give testimony on your part had occasion call'd for it; instead of which, I surprize you with my niece, I find her bath'd in tears, I hear her charge you with an insult: What am I to think of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, I can make no guess at your thoughts, I can only answer for my own.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And what are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
That's rather short let me observe; ome thoughts I shall keep to myself; such as I can
spare are at your service—for instance, I think your niece will be a very handsome bride, and my lord a very happy bridegroom.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Did she inform you that was to happen?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I cannot say she did; it was her plea∣sure to deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then why do you presume to she con∣ry? Did Lord Janus assert he had her consent to mar∣ry him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I have not seen Lord Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: For shame! for shame! I blush to hear you so prevaricate: such meaness let me tell you, scarce deserves a gentleman's resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Meaness! prevaticate! what language is this? I tell you once again I have not seen Lord Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: 'Tis false! I know 'tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Intolerable insult! Draw!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, hold your hands! I'll die between your swords.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: She faints—contain yourself; we'll find another time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: What am I doing? Her emotion sg∣gers me.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Oh the mercy of mercies! what's agoing forward here? Swords out! Miss in a swoon! the lud be good unto us all! Murder and sudden death.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, blockhead! what do you come here for!

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: I cou'd have told you but you have scar'd it out of my head again: I come—(pray, Sir, put up your sword.) [To Sir Charles]—I come—(dear Sir, put it up or I shall swoon too—) his worship bid me come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: She recovers; look up, my dear, no mis∣chief has happen'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Heaven be thank'd! I am sure Sir Charles wou'd not have been so cruel to me, if Lord Janus had not provok'd him to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Why 'tis about Lord Janus I am come, He tells us he has driven you, Sir Charles, out of the country, but under favor I don't perceive you are ar upon your way as yet.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: There, Sir! you said you had not seen Lord Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I say it again and again.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Oh wonderful, what some folks will say! but I beg pardon, pray don't draw your sword again; 'tis only a small slip of your memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I saw his servant and no other person but his servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Who, old Philihert! lud a-mercy, only to hear him—why the old baboon is dead drunk and fast asleep in bed. Under correction your honor's me∣mory is apt to trip.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: What ails the fool? 'twas Harry Singleton I spoke with.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Whuh! that's a good one—Harry Single∣ton forsooth! where does he come from?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Stop! there are more mysteries in this than one: The person you saw, Sir Charles, I saw likewise—Harkye, Oliver, get you out of the way; go back to your master and say I'm coming home with my niece: on your life I charge you not to discover to a soul that you have seen Sir Charles here; let not a word that has now pass'd come out of your lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: May I never put any thing into them again if I do.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I think you said your friend Lord Janus has a servant call'd Harry Singleton.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: His valet de chambre; I know him well.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And he it was who was with you just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: The very man; I told you so: Lord Janus snt him to me with a message.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then Lord Janus carried his own message, aye and wears his own livery, for we know none other.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: No, indeed; his lordship has no servant of that name with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Oh heaven and earth, it flashes shame and conviction in my face! I have been the dupe of an Impostor, how can I ever atone for what I have said? Oh lovely innocent, I have offended past re∣demption.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Come, come, I do not thik so desperate∣ly of your pardon; there seems a spark of kindness for you still lurking in a certain heart, which is not quite made of marble.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I believe Sir Charles has made that dis∣covery some time ago.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: There, there, make the best use of your time for reconciling differences, whilst I step into the village for the proper officers to apprehend these Im∣postors; I don't doubt but I shall find you friends at my return, and then we will all jointly enjoy the lux∣ary of this most fortunate discovery.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir CHARLES and ELEANOR meeting Captain GEORGE.

SP.SPEAKER: GEORGE.
SP.P: WELL, my pretty Eleanor, how has your confe∣rence ended? Are you still inexorable? Must I set to again with this vile man and put him to death before your face, or has he soften'd your hard heart into pity and complacency?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Can't you read his sentence in my eyes?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Oh terrible! it must be a very severe one.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: 'Tis no slight one in good truth, for tho' I have not doom'd him to immediate death, I have consign'd him to perpetual imprisonment for life.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I admire your justice; if you had suffer'd such a criminal to escape out of your hands, I shou'd have been the first to condemn you for your weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: So far from that, I resolve to keep him close prisoner, very close I can assure you; with my good will he shall never be out of my sight for the rest of our days.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
Oh thou enchanting natural creature! with a heart so open, so transparent as thine, an hour's acquaintance is an age of experience; think me not so mere a trifler as to be the captive of a smile, a glance; beauty, if not animated by a soul like thine, has no allurements for me, thou art nature itself and with nature I am safe, but the confidence thou art so ready to repose in me shou'd have better ground to
rest on, than it's own generosity alone; I shall de∣mand a scrutiny before I will accept of my election.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: A very proper compliment you pay to my sagacity, tho' I have shewn you I am capable of dis∣covering the false character and sham pretensions of a counterfeit, you won't credit me for discerning the good and genuine qualities of a man of honor: How is this? I desire to know if truth is not as obvious in it's natural character as falsehood in a feign'd one?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well said, my Eleanor, let him answer that if he can: I am witness you was never dup'd by this sham lord, your natural intuition saw more than our older experience could discover; for my part I did not like him, but I did not absolutely suspect him, and when Sir Charles spoke so highly of his merit, I confess I was fairly stagger'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: So was not I as to my own judgment of Lord Janus; I own I was puzzled how to account for Sir Charles's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: That must have appear'd egregiously absurd—But is it not time we proceeded to the detec∣tion of him?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: With all my heart; my myrmidons are ready, and you must let me stl you into the house by a back way, where I will keep you out of fight till I give the signal for your appearance; what punish∣ment we shall or can inflict upon these rascals will be a future question; there will at least be some amuse∣ment in the discovery: You are not aware perhaps he has an accomplice with him, one Polycarp.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: I have told Sir Charles of that, and been malicious enough to let him into the secret Atalantis of our family.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Ah my poor Dorothy I she has not given me a kind glance since that fellow came into the house; so long as she has been upon the cruize for a mate I shou'd be sorry she shou'd strike to a pirate at last—But come let us lose no more time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: And has this time been lost, my charm∣er?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Not by me at least, if the life that you have sav'd may from this happy moment be devoted to it's preserver.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Come, come, no more love-making, but follow me; I shall lead you thro' a blind and crooked path, where nobody can discover you, but remember it is the path to happiness, and therefore follow bold∣ly.
SP.STAGE: An Apartment in Sir SOLOMON'S House.
SP.P: Now then I can a man again, a man of my own making, a peer by my own patent, lord of my own ascendant; and who suffers by my good fortune? who slts that I may swim Not Sir Charles Freemantle, for him I have dispatch'd upon his travels, and 'twill be bad if he does not come home a wifer man than he set out; not grave Sir Solomon, for he is a fool of his own maling; not even fair Eleanor herself, for I will make her a most loving husband; and why should I alone be call'd an Impostor for a mere flaw in my itle, when there are so many worse impostors about the world, who counterfeit love before marriage and turn tynts after it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Well, my good lord, what news do you give me of Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: The best that can be: You have seen the last of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Marry let him go, and a good riddance say I: I guess'd how-it wou'd be when your lordship took him in hand; I thought he cou'd not have the face to stand his ground.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: To do him justice I had very little trou∣ble in bringing him to a proper understanding of him∣self, as soon as I convinc'd him I was serious in my intentions to make your daughter Lady Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I believe he was inform'd of that by my brother George.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: 'Tis very true, but he was pleas'd to say he wou'd take it upon nobody's word but my own; men of the world, Sir Solomon, are hard to believe that persons of high rank and nobility will step out of their own line for an alliance, when there is so much beauty and attraction amongst their equals, but I have no such pride of nobility about me; my only am∣bition is to be happy, and I persuade myself your ami∣able daughter is the very woman in the world to make me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: My lord, I am fully sensible of your great condescension in accepting of my humble alliance, and I hope, if you can overlook the little awkwardness and reluctances of an inexperienc'd girl like my Eleanor, you will find her mend upon acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Doubt not, Sir Solomon, but I can make allowances for such tristing foibles as I have discover'd in Miss Eleanor; so far from being piqu'd at her seem∣ing partiality for Sir Charles, I like her the better for it: it proves to me that her nature is susceptible of love, and as I hope to render her greater services than he has persorm'd, I don't doubt of meeting greater returns of love than he has receiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Sol.
SP.P:
Your lordship charms me with the gene∣rous candor of your noble sentiments. I do not say to you that my daughter shall obey me, because I trust there will be no such repugnance on her part as may provoke me to compulsion; but be this as it may, at
all events I beg you to conclude the thing as done; and now, my lord, permit me to address you as a mem∣ber of my family, and tell you that there is an affair now in agitation, which gives me great alarm.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: I guess the matter you allude to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I dare say your lordship does, and I hope you have that influence and authority over Mr. Poly∣carp as may prevent it: My cousin Dorothy is an old maid, and as that is a condition not of her own chus∣ing, I am afraid there will be little difficulty in per∣suading her to change it: now, my lord, her fortune, which is no trifle, sleeps in my hands, and if she calls it out in haste, she will disable me from paying down the full sum upon the nail, which I am pledg'd for to your lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Depend upon it, Sir Solomon, I am as annious to prevent this match as you can be, and I will take occasion to talk to Mr. Polycarp in a way, that shall make him desist.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Pray, my lord, if the question be not an improper one, what is Mr. Polycarp's situation in life?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Mr. Polycarp's situation is dependant; I took him into my pay to relieve me from the dudgery of writing letters to agents and auditing accounts with srewards; he understands law, and is no bad scholar, tho' something of the paedagogue, for to say the truth he was awhile ago an usher in a country school; he is by no means of condition to aspire to Mrs. Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: You have said enough, my lord, the country usher is enough, there's an end of Mr. Polycarp, there's not another old damsel in all England so proud of her family as cousin Dorothy: but apropoat here comes my gentleman, with your lordship's leave I will turn him over to you to prepar him for his dismission.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: All joy to you, my noble! you return with stying colors from your expedition.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Aye, my good lad, we are at last in port—
SP.STAGE: We are the Jasons, we have won the fleece.
SP.P: I have made a step out of character, like many of my brother peers, to regale myself with the humours of the vulgar, and now step into it again to laugh at those I have cajol'd by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Then Caesar is himself again—But what is become of Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus
SP.P: Blown into the air upon the bladders of his own credulity: of all the foole, honesty ever made, he is best intitled to wear the cap, and he is now jour∣neying like a caparison'd ass to the jingle of his own bells—But how go you on with your Dorothy?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: A merry pace; if you are not very brisk we shall get the start of you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Nay, jack, if you start your old stager first, I shall never bring my young filley up to the post: you must positively give me the lead.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I must you think; no, no, my master, a free course and no favor! stand to your own conditi∣ons; good faith is to be kept, tho' we deal in the dark.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Do you discredit my honor?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: By no means, I credit you for your honor to the full as much as I do for your title, but I had rather rust to your knavery than either, for knave to knave must be honest or adieu to the trade; therefore you will marry Eleanor when Eleanor is in the mind to marry, and I shall move off with Dorothy, when Do∣rothy will move off with me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: But hark ye, Jack, hear reason; when two projects are on foot together they may clash, and I must fairly tell you you have given an alarm to the family already.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P:
To the family! yes, you are very conside∣rate of the family, are you not? Remember your own parting words just now, when you sneak'd away from
detection like a coward from his colors, and left me to maintain a post you did not dare to stand in; then you was humble enough to ask protection under my shield.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Protection from you! Wretch, didn't I take you out of the gripe of poverty from the very jaws of famine? a starving usher in a country school? promoted you to a share in this great enterprize, fur∣nished and equipt you for it like a gentleman?—And is your hunger now so ravenous as to whet your teeth against your friend? are you so mere a shark as to eat shark? Shame upon you!
SP.STAGE: Sir SOLOMON enters to Lord JANUS.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: My lord, my lord, a word in your ear I pray you step out for a few minutes and leave the field to Dorothy; I have loaded her to the very muzzle, and she is opening such a battery of red hot pride and ridicule against the poor paedagogue, as shall beat his school about his ears in a twinkling; let us get out of their way.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: With all my heart; so I am but reveng'd of that rascal I care not what happens; come along, Sir Solomon.

SP.SPEAKER: POLYCARP.
SP.P: Very well; Mr. Harty Singleton, I'll match you for this insolence; I'll be off with Dorothy this very night, tho' you and your fine project shall be blown into the air by it next morning—Oh! happy fortune, here she comes—
My life, my soul! thus let me fly into your arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Not so fast, friend, not so fast—keep your distance and I will talk to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Why keep my distance my charmer? are we not alone? are we not agreed? What have you now to fear from Solomon or his spies, that you should act with this reserve?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Mistake me not, I have no reserve from Sir Solomon; he and I have talk'd you over very pleasantly I can assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Talk'd me over very pleasantly!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Oh yes, I told him what a fine lover I had got o'the sudden; it's impossible you know not to boast of one's conquests; I have been hammering my brains to recollect the smart things you have been say∣ing to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Really? you have been mmering your brains, have you? very pleasant work truly! And did you hammer out all I have been saying to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: There were but sew hings worth recol∣lecting; them I gave you credit for.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: And my doings—did you not recollect them too? I think, all things consider'd, Mrs. Dorothy, I deserve some credit for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Humph! Impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Well then take the credit of them to your∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Pr'ythee don't be scurrilous; recollect yourself, a man of your sort shou'd be grave and so∣lemn, and, to act in character, you shou'd set an ex∣ample of wisdom and morality to youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Socrates was wise. Madam, and moral too, yet he sometimes fool'd away an hour with the prosti∣gate Aspasia.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: The more shame for him! sor Socrates as I take it was a schoolmaster: What wou'd he have said if one of his petty ushers had so behav'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: So, so! Sir Solomon talk'd that over with you too, did he?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P:
Just so, and would have persuaded me all
your fine speeches were taken out of your schoolboys▪ copybooks.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Pleasant, very pleasant truly! I am to thank my Lord Janus for this retail specimen of his wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: To be sure you are; not but we could have discovered it by your air and manner; there is a good deal of the birch about you.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Whatever there is to spare I wou'd very rea∣dily bestow upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: To be sure Lord Janus made himself rather merry at the idea of your making love; I don't say he has all the wit in the world, but you know his manner; he has infinie vivacity.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I think he has infinite impudence at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Come, come, you must not quarrel with your patron for a joke; people in your dependant sta∣tion must put up with the raillery of their superiors.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: I shall elevate his lordship still higher before I've done with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: It is not in the nature of things you know to suppose a person of your sort could have seri∣ous hopes of marrying me.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: That's true, I only thought of it at a dis∣tance, as a man thinks of hanging, when he takes a purse upon the road; the halter might be in my thoughts, tho' the noose was not round my neck.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: You deal in delicate allusions truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: And yet I had rather take the allusion than the lady at any time; a good tough rope, that ends all plagues at once, is better than a tough old woman, whose plagues there is no end to.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Well, Sir. I shall recommend you to the alternative, and yet, to do you justice, you took due pains to obtain the lady and escape the rope.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Yes, I might perhaps have put up with the old hen, if it had not been or her cackling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: And yet 'tis no more than you have been pretty well wonted to; there are a great many tongues going in a school.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Aye, but there is a joyful time in a school, call'd breaking-up time; had I seen my damsel in the way of breaking up, I might have stood the tug in hopes of holidays hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: I hope I interrupt no business.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: No, my lord, you come very opportunely, for I had run out my stock of compliments, and got to the last copy in the book; and really this fair lady has been so kind in consequence of your flattering re∣port of me, that love and vanity have nearly turn'd your poor paedagogue's brain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Vanity I admit, but what do you mean by love?

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: More than most men mean, who profess it—sincerity; for instance, when I said but now it was the blooming bride-maid, not the bride herself, I shou'd gaze upon with rapture, it was you I had in my eye—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: 'Tis false; he said no such thing, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: When I said I envied not my lord his happi∣ness, sigh'd not for those scenes of splendor, those vast possessions, those fine castles that await him—in the air, it was because I thought of you, my angel!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: I desire you will not think of me any more, nor speak of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: When I said you was the very idol of my soul, that your voice was harmony and your eyes heven—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Pt'ythee no more of this stuff.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: That your smiles were sunshine and your temper soft, serene, enlivening as the light which it diffuses, 'twas you, you only I was then describing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Stop your saucy tongue. My Lord Janus, will you suffer me to be thus insulted in your presence,

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P:
When I was pleasantly talking you over in this manner, and hammering my poor brains to recol∣lect
all the soft things you had said, and all the kind things you had done—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Janus.
SP.P: Hold, Mr. Polycarp, this goes too far—Madam, I intreat you to retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: I will, my lord, and out of this house, if such insolence is not corrected.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus
SP.P: Hark ye, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus
SP.P: I don't like these jests.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: No more does she, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus
SP.P: Nor will I allow of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: You shall repent of this, Mr. Polycarp.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: You had best not put me upon that Mr. Sin∣gleon, for fear I should repent of your company at the same time, and consign you over to the executi∣oner for your patent.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Is it come to this? do you threnten to impech me, villai, informer? I'll ear your threat out first
SP.STAGE: Sir SOLOMON and OLIVER enter hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Heyday! what's here to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Help, help, good Christian people! the little man will be murder'd by the great man.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Sir Solomon here! hush, hush, man! say no mre; let go your hold; I'll bring you off.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Ah, noble Captain, I am glad you're come; for once in your life step out of your office, and keep the peace between these passionate gentlemen

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: My good friend Oliver, did I look as if I was in a passion?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P:
Did you look as if you was in a passion? yes, no lord need be in a greater, and you spoke as if you was in a passion too—Only mind me, Captain
George—(mimicks him) Villain! Informer! do you threaten to impeach me? I'll tear your throat out first.—That was it; there you have it to the life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I am all astonishment. Those were the very words.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: They were so; you are right as to the words; you are correct in the words, Sir Solomon, and your Pierrot mimicks them pretty well.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Don't I? Villain, Informer!—then I am to catch hold of Mr. Polycarp by the throat, isn't it so, my lord? but if I had been in the little man's shoes I cou'd have plac'd a blow where your lordship wou'dn't have lik'd it, you was open at the fifth button.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Hush, Oliver, be silent.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: And so you both thought me in a real passion—you cou'd not flatter me more. I believe, Captain, you did not come in time to see the rehear∣sal.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No, but I hope I am not too late or the conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Well, Polycarp, methinks we came pret∣ty well off in our quarrelling scene this time: we shall get up this play with some .

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: If too many rehearsals don't spoil it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: What the dickens! were you only acting a play all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Only acting a play, Sir Solomon! What else is the whole beau monde employed about? I do but as the rest of my brother nobles: I am sitting up the great hall in Janus Castle for my theatre; there's an end of all old-fashion'd customs, instead of dinners of five courses, we serve you up dramas of five acts; feast your ears and fast your stomachs.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Confound the fellow! his ingenuity almost excuses his iniquity.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Well to be sure if you call this a play, I have seen many a one in my time and never thought the actors in earnest before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P:
Hold your tongue, sirrah! but, my lord, a word or two about this play—I am pretty well vers'd
in the poets, and don't remember any thing about tearing a gentleman's throat out on the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir Solomon, there is great tearing of throats on the stage, but you must know this piece is in manuscript; the author's modesty don't mean to publish.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: If my lord is the author, I dare say he does not with his name to be known.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: No truly, if his lordship comes into the world it will be under a feign'd title.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: So cousin Dorothy, you come too late for the rehearsal; my lord and Mr. Polycarp have been performing in a very capital stie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor
SP.P: What is it you mean? what has his lord∣ship performing?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Oh! such a scene of fire and fury—Poor Mr. Polycarp had lke to have been fangled by the hemence of his acting.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: What tell you me of acting? His lord∣ship feels a proper indignation for the insults I have receiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Pooh! child, 'twas only part of a play they were repeating.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: I understand hie lordship's delicacy in giving it that turn, and I hold myself for ever bound to him for taking up my cause so warmly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Really, Madam, you give me more credit than I deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Come, come, be silent upon that subject, you will but expose yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Now you have been properly chastised, I hope I shall no more be troubled with your imper∣tinence: A palry paedagogue indeed to talk in such a stile to a person of my sort—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Why, who talks to a person of your sort? Can't you be persuaded that nobody thought about you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: If nobody thought more about me than you, or the doughty Captain there, I might have been subjected to any indignities in your house, but my Lord Janus has the spirit of a nobleman, and will not suffer a lady to be insulted with impunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Well, Madam, I consess you have reason to be offended; I have certainly omitted some points of civility, which you had a right to expect, and so to set all matters strait, I'll leave the house this very moment.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Say, Sir!—You have had your play, let us have our's; the performers -e all ready, and only wait the prompter's signal; I'll touch the bell and let 'em enter.
SP.STAGE: Captain GEORGE rings a bell, and Sir Charles FREE∣MANTLE enters with ELEANOR and Constables.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus
SP.P: My death-warrant by all that's terrible!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Heyday! who are these?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Very capital performers some of them; these worthy fellows play the parts of constables; the ladies were to have been married in the play to a pair of the most infamous sharpers in the kingdom, but they have escap'd out of their clutches; this gentleman, who is nothing better than a lord's lacquey, plays the part of his master; this other gentleman, who is his brother in iniquity, has been seized by the throat in the play, and by the throat will be seiz'd when it is over: the manager and director of the whole move∣ment, to whom alone we are indebted for the happy turn of the plot, you behold in this worthy baronet, the benefactor, friend and preserver of us all.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: I hope, noble Captain, you will not for∣get to reserve a part for the hangman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Mercy of mercies, have I been dup'd, gull'd, bamboozled after all?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Egregiously, my good brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: To be sure you have. Cou'd not you find out your Imposter as readily as I did mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Perhaps his worship did not look so close as you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Come, you are well off; hold your tongue and be thankful.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Sir Solomon, I congratulate you on your escape. You have been harbouring a knavish lacquey under a counterseited title of a noble lord.—Now, Mr. Harry Singleton, stand forth! What have you to say for yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: Very little, Sir Charles. I have cer∣tainly made free with his lordship's title; but I have endeavoured to do it all the honor in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: You do it honor, sirrah! how can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus.
SP.P: By bestowing it on the most amiable young lady in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: Well, Sir, there is some ingenuity in your defence, but it would be an injury to mankind to let such a fellow loose upon the world; Sir Solomon, you are an acting magistrate, you will make out his commitment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: I an acting magistrate, Sir Charles! I am an acting fool if you please; give him his dismission, and send me to the house of correction in his room.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: If I might advise, your worship shou'd turn him over to the jurymen in livery, and then he will be tried by his peers.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Janus
SP.P: Oh Sir Charles Freemantle, I be seech you to take pity upon a poor young fellow, who has known better days, and been corrupted by the evil ha∣bits of that fraternity, into which his hard fortune in∣listed him; put me into any humble way of life, and I will be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Canting rascal! I always thought you wou'd die dunghill at the last.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Heyday, here's a sturdy spirit! 'tis a pity we have no pressgangs going: Cousin Dorothy, what shall we do with this fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dor.
SP.P: Do with him! there's no doing any thing with him let the law deal with him as he de∣serves.

SP.SPEAKER: Polyc.
SP.P: Mitigate my sentence I beseech you: save me from matrimony, and I submit to transportation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Well, my child, all joy to you: 'Tis the first match I have attempted to make for you, and it shall be the last: hereafter let your own inclinations be your guide.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I believe, Eleanor, I can pretty nearly guess which way they will lead you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleanor.
SP.P: Ah, my dear uncle, you have a talent for discoveries.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Sir Solomon, you have no impostor now to deal with; my character will meet the scru∣tiny. May I not aspire to claim what I have been so happy as to save?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: With all my heart and my blessing to boot; I know of you well, Sir Charles, and shall be proud of your alliance. Now let us have a general gaol delivery, and since his mock lordship has fairly brought his drama to it's catastrophe, let us drop our curtain and humbly hope for the plaudit of your hands.

LG.L: CUNNING projectors may pretend to find
A scheme for sailing ships against the wind,
But never poet yet cou'd start a scheme
For navigating plays against the stream:
Oh heavens! no sooner does your angry gale
Hiss in his teeth, then back goes every sail,
Furious he drives—Ah, dreadful situation!
Stern foremost down the rapides of damnation.
Yet here and there a sturdy wit has try'd
To pull and tug and puff against the tide,
But what is one poor puff of his own making,
When all around him the wild waves are breaking?
Plung'd in the gulph like Ceyx still he raves,
Murmuring his own applause beneath the waves.
Magnetic quacks can stare you into fits,
No muscle stirs for our magnetic wits;
Stomachs there are that can digest a stone,
Your's will not gulp a little nonsense down.
Now this is hard, for till your tastes agree,
How can we know what comedy shou'd be?
"Reform," Sir Courtly cries, "reform your stage!
"Polish your mirror that reflects the age,
"Copy from France, give your Apollo grace,
"And with pearl powder deck your Muse's face!"
"Oh, rot your delicacy!—Give me sun,"
Sir Balaam Blubber cries, "My dreary Dun
"Against your Pegasus nine nights to three;
"That is your only galloper for me:
"John Bull's my man, I love his honest roar,
"I come to laugh, or I come here no more."
Not so Miss Biddy—she is all for feeling,
For sentiment, for sighing, sobbing, kneeling;
Rope-ladders she admires and closet scenes,
Escapes, surprizes, hudlings behind screens,
And ever when two meanings mask the jest,
Miss Biddy's purity picks out the best.
Stand by, make way! Lady Bell Blossom's places ▪
Slap goes the door and round go all your faces;
In comes her ladyship with vacant stare,
Smiles heav'n knows why, and cursies heav'n knows where.
Ask now what says my lady to the matter,
What does she like?—Her own incessant chatter.
For me, tho' poets various arts employ
To make me wife, maid, widow, man and boy,
Yet all this while there's but one thing in nature
I truly aim to be—Your faithful creature:
Here I'm at home; this is my natural part;
This character flows freely from my heart.
